entry.title: MLB: What to watch on August 26, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Philadelphia Phillies @ New York Mets, 4:10p

Summary

Today‚Äôs top-shelf watchability pick pits the Mets‚Äô barrel parade against a 96-mph lefty who just blanked them earlier this summer. With Zack Wheeler out for the year, this is also a Luzardo-as-bellwether litmus test for Philly‚Äôs October plans.

At gNERD 18.33, this sits at the very top of today‚Äôs slate and well into the historic elite, and the reasons are obvious: pNERD loves Jes√∫s Luzardo (9.38) for the power/whiff/tempo combo, and he recently spun 6 2/3 scoreless vs. New York; Sean Manaea (7.29) brings command and pace but has battled late-start fade, with the Mets dropping his last five turns. The lineup side juices tNERD: the Mets‚Äô bats (11.82) have been a top barrel-and-baserunning watch, while Philly (8.16) mixes real baserunning value with star thump. If you prefer names to numbers, think Schwarber/Turner/Harper versus Soto/Alonso/Nimmo, with Soto leading the Mets in homers and Alonso the RBI drumbeat.

Narratively, Wheeler‚Äôs thoracic outlet surgery raises Luzardo‚Äôs importance from nice-to-have to tone-setter for a rotation now leaning on S√°nchez/Su√°rez/Nola behind him. That real-world stress layered onto a strength-versus-strength matchup is precisely what makes this one pop.

(A model from OpenAI generated the above text using instructions, the NERD scores, and these sources: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6.)

Arizona Diamondbacks @ Milwaukee Brewers, 4:40p

Summary

A 100-mph upstart versus a playoff-grade lineup is a fine excuse to find the remote. Misiorowski‚Äôs gas plus Milwaukee‚Äôs madcap baserunning against Arizona‚Äôs lively bats and leaky bullpen makes for tense, swing-heavy viewing.

At a 15.23 gNERD, this sits above the 95th percentile of historic games here, and today‚Äôs inputs explain why: Misiorowski‚Äôs pNERD (10.73) leads the slate and his xFIP- (77) plus 99 mph heat promise whiffs and weak contact, with reports noting he lives at triple digits and is already racking 100+ mph pitches at a Greene-adjacent clip. Pfaadt (pNERD 4.42; xFIP- 99) is steadier than splashy and coming off 7 efficient innings last time out, but his contact profile can get loud, which Arizona‚Äôs defense will need to help manage. The Brewers‚Äô tNERD (9.73) is buoyed by elite run game and run prevention‚Äîthink top-tier steals and a deep bullpen‚Äîwhile the D-backs bring top-10 bats but a bullpen that adds late drama. Milwaukee is dinged by absences (e.g., Chourio, Hoskins), yet Yelich‚Äôs August heater keeps the lineup dangerous.

San Diego Padres @ Seattle Mariners, 6:40p

Summary

Cal Raleigh just joined the 50-homer club and Seattle‚Äôs division chase meets San Diego‚Äôs souped‚Äëup, Miller‚Äëboosted bullpen‚Äîthis Vedder Cup installment actually has teeth. With a gNERD of 12.38‚Äîwell above today‚Äôs average‚Äîtwo bat-missing righties plus late‚Äëinning leverage make this a prime channel‚Äëstick.

Cease‚Äôs 97 mph octane and above‚Äëaverage run prevention indicators (second‚Äëhalf K% 33%, August xFIP ~3.9) power his pNERD 7.65, a clear edge over Castillo‚Äôs 5.06. Seattle did add real thump‚Äîhello, Josh Naylor‚Äîand Raleigh‚Äôs milestone night set the tone, but Castillo arrives needing a clean reset after allowing 19 hits over his last 8 innings.

Castillo‚Äôs run suppression tends to travel poorly this year (home wOBA allowed .261 vs .353 away), so if Cease misses bats early, the Padres‚Äô strongest watchability hook becomes their bullpen cavalry, now headlined by 101‚Äëmph Mason Miller. Seattle‚Äôs bats still barrel better than league average, though, so there‚Äôs swing‚Äëand‚Äëmiss theater on both sides.

Padres tNERD (7.31) leans on elite relief and a top broadcast; Mariners tNERD (4.74) rides power more than gloves. With Jackson Merrill on the IL and Seattle fresh off Raleigh‚Äôs history and a standings squeeze, this rates near the top tier for today.

Atlanta Braves @ Miami Marlins, 3:40p

Summary

A rookie buzzsaw versus a rehabbing Cy Young is a fine way to spend nine innings. With a gNERD of 11.91, this leans pitching-first, and that‚Äôs mostly Hurston Waldrep‚Äôs doing.

Waldrep‚Äôs pNERD (10.09) sits near the top of the historical distribution, backed by a 76 xFIP- and mid‚Äë90s heat, plus a brisk tempo that keeps the channel‚Äësurfing impulse at bay; he just spun seven scoreless with seven Ks and is 4-0 across his first four turns, including 6 IP of one‚Äërun ball against these Marlins. Sandy Alcantara‚Äôs name carries weight, his velocity is back, and he set season highs with nine strikeouts and 114 pitches his last time out, but the 2025 version has been more ordinary (xFIP- 106) even as the repertoire tweaks and heavy ground‚Äëball profile hint at upside if the slider behaves.

The team side is less electric (average tNERD 4.43): Miami‚Äôs youth bumps their score while both bullpens grade out as adventure‚Äëprone, which quietly adds chaos equity late. Atlanta‚Äôs lineup is thinner with Austin Riley done for the year, though Sean Murphy‚Äôs return helps. If you like mound cat‚Äëand‚Äëmouse with a nonzero chance of late-inning weirdness, this rates above today‚Äôs average.

Tampa Bay Rays @ Cleveland Guardians, 3:40p

Summary

Shane Baz‚Äôs underlying ace act meets Parker Messick‚Äôs shiny new‚Äëtoy debut, with Cleveland‚Äôs bullpen ready to slam the door and Tampa Bay‚Äôs track team daring the Guardians‚Äô battery to keep up. This grades as a ‚Äúwatch‚Äù because the stuff is loud, the stakes matter, and the unknowns are interesting.

The gNERD sits at 11.84, comfortably above today‚Äôs average, and the pNERD split explains why: Baz‚Äôs 6.45 reflects real bat‚Äëmissing traits ‚Äî a mid‚Äëto‚Äëupper‚Äë90s heater and a hard, two‚Äëplane curve ‚Äî that have produced elite expected results (xERA 2.44, .257 xwOBA, .177 xBA, 31.6% K%) even when the surface line wobbles. Messick‚Äôs 0.00 pNERD just means we lack a sample; his debut was anything but empty: 6.2 IP, 6 K, 1 ER with strike‚Äëthrowing and a legit changeup, the exact profile that can blunt Tampa Bay‚Äôs right‚Äëhanded thump. Team‚Äëwise, Cleveland‚Äôs offense has lagged (bottom tier by wRC+), but its bullpen remains a strength, so runs early matter. That‚Äôs countered by a Rays club that leads MLB in steals, which inflates the ‚Äúfun‚Äù quotient via pressure and chaos on the bases. Add it up: above‚Äëpar gNERD, a bat‚Äëmisser vs. a rookie with feel, and late‚Äëinning reliever theater ‚Äî worth a primary screen.

Chicago Cubs @ San Francisco Giants, 6:45p

Summary

A high-gear Cubs offense/defense meets a name-brand Giants headliner and a patched bullpen; contrast is the draw. Verlander‚Äôs milestone tour plus San Francisco‚Äôs season-long issues vs lefties turn a merely solid gNERD into a worthwhile check-in.

Probables are Matthew Boyd vs Justin Verlander, a tidy power-vs-guile matchup that our model pegs as mid-pack on the mound (avg pNERD 4.1), with Boyd (5.2) edging Verlander (3.0). Boyd‚Äôs watchability is skill-based: a better-than-average xFIP- (96) and command profile, now paired with a first All-Star nod that tracks with his run of quality starts. The matchup slants toward Chicago‚Äôs bats and gloves anyway: top-tier barrels, baserunning, and fielding drive a big tNERD edge, while the Giants have been among MLB‚Äôs worst vs lefties (.611 OPS/.212 AVG). Verlander remains appointment viewing for history‚Äîhe crossed 3,500 career Ks this month‚Äîand he‚Äôs never taken a loss to the Cubs in the regular season, even if the underlying indicators now read more mortal. San Francisco also moved late-inning anchors Tyler Rogers and Camilo Doval at the deadline, thinning the finish if this stays tight. Given a gNERD of 10.96‚Äîabove today‚Äôs average and our historical median‚Äîplus a surging Cubs club fresh off a sweep, this rates ‚Äúclick over during commercials‚Äù worthy.

Washington Nationals @ New York Yankees, 4:05p

Summary

A watchability coin flip: MacKenzie Gore‚Äôs bat-missing left arm (top‚Äëquartile pNERD) takes on the Yankees‚Äô barrel brigade, while 2024 ROY Luis Gil is fresh off a lat‚Äëstrain return and still proving where his strikes live. gNERD 10.57 lands around the middle of today‚Äôs slate (slightly above the historical median), but the volatility is the hook.

New York‚Äôs high tNERD (8.35) is driven by elite contact quality, so any mistake gets punished, and that‚Äôs especially relevant if Gil‚Äôs command wobbles; he‚Äôs three August starts into his comeback and has issued eight walks in 14 innings after a spring high‚Äëgrade lat strain and a 2024 season that led MLB in free passes. Washington‚Äôs tNERD (0.83) is weighed down by light bats and defense, and they may still be without Keibert Ruiz (concussion IL), thinning the lineup. The Yankees‚Äô star power is tempered by Aaron Judge DH‚Äëing while easing back from an elbow issue and not quite at his early‚Äëseason pace, which nudges this toward competitive rather than lopsided.

Gore remains the swing factor: 10.75 K/9 with a 3.69 FIP/3.61 xFIP and a curveball that‚Äôs become a real bat‚Äëmisser. If he locates that breaker, this plays like an upset watch; if not, the Bronx bats justify the tNERD.

Detroit Tigers @ Athletics, 7:05p

Summary

This is a lineup-forward watch: two lively offenses (average tNERD 7.86) and a gNERD of 10.37 make the bats the draw while the starters mostly set the table. If you want strikeout theater, look elsewhere; if you want traffic, tactics, and some chaos potential, settle in.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on August 25, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Detroit Tigers @ Athletics, 7:05p

Summary

It‚Äôs Skubal Day, and the gNERD agrees: this is the one you make time for. A slate-topping 17.59 comes from pairing an elite pNERD for Tarik Skubal with two above‚Äëaverage tNERDs in a compact, sold‚Äëout Sacramento setting.

Skubal has leveled up from his Cy season, leading qualified starters in Stuff+ and riding a four‚Äëseam/change/sinker mix that misses bats and limits damage; his 2025 line features elite strikeout and walk rates to match. He just authored seven scoreless with 10 K and 25 whiffs against Houston, the kind of bully-ball that pNERD was built to flag. On the other side, J.T. Ginn‚Äôs sinker‚Äëslider profile is fun in theory and streaky in practice: he‚Äôs punched out righties in bunches but has been far shakier versus lefties, especially at home, a split that tilts toward Detroit‚Äôs left‚Äëhanded thump. Statcast agrees on the shape of the risk: the slider gets whiffs but, when contacted, has played loud; the sinker invites contact that isn‚Äôt always soft.

Add Detroit‚Äôs above‚Äëaverage barrels and aggressive baserunning to the Skubal show, and you‚Äôve got watchable innings even when the bats cool. The Athletics‚Äô big positive ‚Äúluck‚Äù only sweetens the potential for noisy regression.

Philadelphia Phillies @ New York Mets, 4:10p

Summary

This one earns a premium slot because it‚Äôs high-skill meets high-stakes: Cristopher S√°nchez‚Äôs legitimately plus peripherals take on a thumping Mets lineup, while Kodai Senga brings name recognition but iffier indicators. With Zack Wheeler shelved for the year, the Phillies‚Äô rotation depth is suddenly the story within the story.

gNERD 15.93 is propelled by strong tNERDs on both sides, and S√°nchez‚Äôs pNERD (9.48) is the real headline: his 2025 FIP/xFIP have sat in the mid-2s with stout K-BB splits against both lefties and righties, and since June he‚Äôs led qualified starters in run prevention, which passes the smell test for watchability. Senga‚Äôs results have been good on the surface, but under the hood at Citi Field he‚Äôs pairing a walk rate north of 11% with an xFIP around 4.2, and lefties have drawn free passes at an even higher clip, giving Philadelphia‚Äôs left-handed thump real leverage. Add in a divisional race that just tightened because of Wheeler‚Äôs absence, and you‚Äôve got quality plus consequence.

Translation: tune in for S√°nchez‚Äôs sequencing and ground-ball craft against a lineup that punishes mistakes, then stick around to see whether Senga‚Äôs ghost fork can mask the control risk long enough to get through the Phillies‚Äô lefties.

Cincinnati Reds @ Los Angeles Dodgers, 7:10p

Summary

A high‚Äëoctane ace versus a star‚Äëpowered lineup, plus a post‚ÄëTJ wild card, makes this a premium watch. With a gNERD of 14.75‚Äîwell above today‚Äôs average and near the top historically‚Äîthere‚Äôs real substance behind the sizzle.

Hunter Greene‚Äôs big pNERD tracks with the stuff: 99‚Äì100 mph heat, a souped‚Äëup slider, and sharper strike‚Äëthrowing, all translating to underlying run prevention (3.42 FIP) rather than just a shiny line. He also returned from the IL two weeks ago with six scoreless, looking every bit the headliner again. The Dodgers supply the tNERD backbone: a top‚Äëtier offense and deep pen, lately flexed by Shohei Ohtani‚Äôs 45th homer and Freddie Freeman‚Äôs multi‚ÄëHR game as they head home tied atop the NL West. Emmet Sheehan adds intrigue; 13 months off Tommy John, he‚Äôs back in a six‚Äëman setup and has been serviceable with a solid K:BB since activation.

NERD says the watch here is Greene‚Äôs whiffs versus LA‚Äôs patience and damage; Cincinnati‚Äôs low tNERD offense means his margin is thin, and the Dodgers‚Äô bullpen advantage can tilt late. If you like velocity, swing‚Äëand‚Äëmiss, and a lineup capable of punishing any mistake, this one earns your screen.

Arizona Diamondbacks @ Milwaukee Brewers, 4:40p

Summary

Brandon Woodruff‚Äôs remodeled fastball (the four-seamer owns the best whiff rate among starters) meets a Diamondbacks lineup running a 111 wRC+, with Milwaukee‚Äôs baserunning chaos lurking on every pitch. A gNERD of 13.03 puts this in today‚Äôs upper tier and above the historic 75th percentile.

Woodruff‚Äôs velocity is down to ~93, but the cutter/fastball tweak is still shredding bats, which tracks with his strong pNERD; he‚Äôs the draw on the mound. Eduardo Rodr√≠guez brings the other side of the contrast: a modest pNERD (2.66) driven by a below-average xFIP- (107) and muted whiffs, so Arizona‚Äôs watchability leans more on the bats than the starter. The Brewers‚Äô big tNERD (9.72) is built on havoc and prevention‚Äî138 steals, +13.6 BsR, and hefty team defense‚Äîbefitting a club that just ripped a 14-game win streak; that style tends to keep every single in motion. Arizona‚Äôs tNERD (5.76) reflects real thump (Perdomo/Carroll/Marte) but a thinned bullpen‚ÄîKevin Ginkel on the 60-day IL and Ryan Thompson only now tracking back‚Äîcan make late innings swingy. If you‚Äôre prioritizing pitching craft plus action on the bases, and a live chance of bullpen drama, Woodruff vs. Rodr√≠guez is your play; probables are confirmed.

Los Angeles Angels @ Texas Rangers, 5:05p

Summary

If you like ace-versus-flamethrower with a side of narrative, this is your watch: Jacob deGrom‚Äôs fully operational Death Star meets Jos√© Soriano‚Äôs upper-90s sinker, and the gNERD knows it. Pitching drives the ticket here (average pNERD 9.11), pushing a gNERD of 12.36‚Äîwell above today‚Äôs average and near the top quarter historically.

DeGrom is back to being DeGrom: an All-Star again in 2025 with a run of 14 straight starts of 5+ innings and ‚â§2 runs allowed, and he‚Äôs been especially stingy at Globe Life (6‚Äì3, 2.11 ERA, 0.92 WHIP in 12 home starts). Soriano returns to the rotation after a brief paternity/restricted-list stint and just held Texas to one run with seven strikeouts in their late-July meeting, a tidy reminder of why his pNERD is comfortably above average.

The teams themselves won‚Äôt sell you‚ÄîAngels‚Äô defense/bullpen sag, Rangers‚Äô bats have underwhelmed‚Äîbut Texas brings plus baserunning/fielding to keep the ball in motion, and deGrom‚Äôs command/velo duel nicely with Soriano‚Äôs pace and heat. The bet is simple: watch for whiffs, weak contact, and a few high-leverage Rangers dashes rather than a slugfest. If you prioritize elite run prevention over fireworks, this one belongs high on your list.

Washington Nationals @ New York Yankees, 4:05p

Summary

Hard-throwing rookie vs. contact-management upstart: Cam Schlittler‚Äôs upper-90s fastball and breaker meet Brad Lord‚Äôs sinker/4-seamer cocktail that kills barrels and piles grounders. With a gNERD of 12.10‚Äîabove today‚Äôs average and just into the historic upper quartile‚Äîthis rates as a real watch.

Schlittler (pNERD 8.03) just carried a perfect game into the seventh and punched out eight over 6.2 scoreless, part of a month in which he‚Äôs run a 2.08 ERA while showing the Yankees‚Äô hardest heaters of 2025; that‚Äôs precisely the power-stuff upside pNERD is flagging. On the other side, Lord (pNERD 6.86) has shifted from multi-inning weapon to sturdy starter: roughly 95 with extreme arm-side run, a near-50% ground-ball rate, FIP around 3.6, and a barrel rate well above average‚Äîfewer whiffs, more damage control, which suits Yankee Stadium tension nicely. The lineup contrast boosts watchability: New York just bludgeoned Boston behind two homers apiece from Jazz Chisholm Jr. and Trent Grisham, and their post-break baserunning has spiked to complement top-tier power‚Äîwhile Aaron Judge remains limited to DH as his throwing ramps back up. If you enjoy the ‚Äúcan a contact suppressor thread the needle against a sledgehammer offense?‚Äù vibe, this is your game.

The pNERD edge tilts to Cabrera, and there‚Äôs substance behind it: his mid- to upper‚Äë90s velocity and that absurd changeup headline a season with a mid‚Äë3s FIP, the byproduct of a more balanced mix and better feel for his non‚Äëfastballs. With a gNERD of 10.55, this sits a tick below today‚Äôs slate average but near the historical median‚Äîwatchable because the components tug in opposite directions. Bibee (projected: 9-9, ~4.6 FIP-adjacent run prevention with a ~3:1 K:BB) is good-not-dominant, and he‚Äôs coming off a start where he yielded four to Arizona; that makes Cleveland‚Äôs late innings the real variable now that Cade Smith and friends are sharing save chances. Rookie Ian Seymour has a pNERD of 0 here only because the sample‚Äôs thin; the intrigue is real: the Rays‚Äô lefty debuted in June, has been a swingman in the majors, and carried a 30%+ K rate at Triple-A behind a plus changeup.

Team-wise, both clubs‚Äô midrange tNERDs hide quirks: Tampa Bay runs well and the pen is sturdy, while Cleveland‚Äôs run prevention leans on gloves and depth‚Äîbut that unsettled ninth adds volatility, and therefore entertainment. If you like contrasts‚Äîmethodical Bibee versus the unknown lefty and a high-leverage coin flip late‚Äîthis deserves a look.

Curiosity watch: can NPB command artist Tomoyuki Sugano keep Boston‚Äôs bats quiet again while Baltimore‚Äôs closer-by-committee holds its nerve? It‚Äôs a low-gNERD game buoyed by Boston‚Äôs high tNERD, with Sugano‚Äôs MLB acclimation and a Red Sox opener supplying the intrigue.

At 8.01, this gNERD sits near the low end of today‚Äôs slate, but Boston‚Äôs 9.12 tNERD props it up: barrels, baserunning, defense, and a bullpen our model likes. Baltimore lags (3.26), and its back end is thinner after F√©lix Bautista‚Äôs shoulder surgery forced a committee that lately has featured Keegan Akin grabbing five-out saves. Sugano is the baseball reason to sample: the ex-Yomiuri ace just held Boston to one unearned run and has steadied of late with results outpacing whiffs. Boston counters with lefty Brennan Bernardino as an opener one day after a short outing, likely handing bulk to Richard Fitts; early left-on-left damage may be muted before the chessboard flips to the pens. Roster subplot: the Red Sox just added Nathaniel Lowe to plug a Casas-sized hole at first, giving the lineup another competent left-handed bat against Sugano.

San Diego Padres @ Seattle Mariners, 6:40p

Summary

This one‚Äôs a bullpen-and-storylines watch, not an ace-off: with a low gNERD (7.38) and both starters carrying bottom-tier pNERDs, the entertainment here likely arrives after the fifth inning. Seattle just got its rotation ‚Äúback,‚Äù but Bryce Miller is fresh off the elbow shelf and allowed four in five in his return, while San Diego recalled JP Sears after a demotion and he answered with a quality start ‚Äî volatility on both sides is the feature.

The model says ‚Äúmeh‚Äù at first pitch ‚Äî both xFIP- marks (Sears 114, Miller 118) and modest miss rates explain the low pNERDs ‚Äî but there‚Äôs intrigue if it‚Äôs tight late. San Diego supercharged an already excellent relief corps by trading for Mason Miller, and MLB‚Äôs own write‚Äëup noted that group had been best‚Äëin‚Äëclass over the season‚Äôs first four months; the contrast with Seattle‚Äôs recently overtaxed staff is stark.

For bats, Cal Raleigh‚Äôs power and the reunion with Eugenio Su√°rez give Seattle thump, while San Diego‚Äôs higher tNERD (7.16) plus a top-tier bullpen and competent contact game can grind out runs and shorten games. If you‚Äôre triaging the slate, this sits toward the low end, but close-and-late leverage ‚Äî Padres pen versus a Mariners group still finding its shape ‚Äî could still be sticky viewing.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on August 24, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Los Angeles Dodgers @ San Diego Padres, 1:10p

Summary

Top of today‚Äôs watchability board and comfortably above the historical median, this Dodgers‚ÄìPadres tilt blends an ace-level duel with late-inning theater. It‚Äôs Yamamoto‚Äôs refined whiffs and command against Pivetta‚Äôs Padres reinvention, with San Diego‚Äôs All-Star bullpen lurking to decide it.

The gNERD is inflated by strong pNERDs on both sides, headlined by Yoshinobu Yamamoto (xFIP- 77; plus velo), whose year-two surge has quieted last season‚Äôs shoulder concerns and earned him a 2025 All-Star nod; the results have matched the skills. Nick Pivetta isn‚Äôt just ‚Äústeady‚Äù‚Äîhe‚Äôs been a legitimate Petco problem, carrying top-10 run prevention and excellent home splits after an offseason move to San Diego and a blistering start that rewrote franchise debut records.

Team watchability holds up: the Dodgers bring barrels and runs even when shorthanded, with recent damage from Freeman and Pages while Shohei Ohtani briefly sat after a comebacker. The Padres‚Äô tNERD is buoyed by a bullpen that‚Äôs both deep and decorated‚Äîthree All-Star relievers (Robert Suarez, Jason Adam, Adrian Morejon) and consistent late-game run prevention make any tight score worth sticking around for.

If you like premium starting stuff giving way to matchup-heavy chess in the seventh and beyond, this is the game‚Äîhigh skill on the mound, competent bats, and real stakes without the slog.

Athletics @ Seattle Mariners, 1:10p

Summary

Colorado Rockies @ Pittsburgh Pirates, 9:05a

Summary

Come for the Paul Skenes show against baseball‚Äôs least dangerous lineup; stay for the chaos of a debuting Rockie trying to survive PNC. Colorado is skipping Triple‚ÄëA and tossing McCade Brown straight into his first MLB start.

The gNERD sits at 9.61‚Äîmid‚Äëpack today‚Äîbecause the teams drag it down (average tNERD 1.57), but Skenes‚Äô pNERD 11.09 turns this into appointment viewing. His arsenal still hums at 98.2 mph with elite shape, and Pittsburgh has hinted at dialing back his workload down the stretch, so don‚Äôt expect a marathon. The matchup is friendly: the Pirates‚Äô bats are bottom‚Äëof‚Äëthe‚Äëleague by runs, power, and OPS, which is why even a merely competent start from Skenes often looks dominant in the box score.

Brown is legitimately intriguing‚ÄîTJ in 2023, big strikeout rates in High‚ÄëA/Double‚ÄëA this year, but he hasn‚Äôt worked past 5‚Öî and arrives because Colorado just cut Austin Gomber. Expect a quick hook into a rough bullpen. One late‚Äëgame wrinkle: the Pirates weakened their relief corps at the deadline by trading David Bednar and Caleb Ferguson, and results have sagged since. If Skenes exits early, the door cracks open.

Net: watch for Skenes‚Äô precision and velocity; watch to see whether Brown‚Äôs raw stuff plays before attrition takes over.

Chicago Cubs @ Los Angeles Angels, 1:07p

Summary

Kyle Hendricks draws his old team with a pitch-to-contact blueprint that should shove every ball in play toward Chicago‚Äôs slick gloves ‚Äî and Los Angeles‚Äô not-so-slick ones. With Jameson Taillon back and throwing strikes, plus the Cubs‚Äô lineup freshly detonated in Anaheim, this is more stress test than strikeout show.

At a gNERD of 8.93, this sits below today‚Äôs average largely because the pNERD pairing (Taillon 4.32, Hendricks 2.05) tilts modest; the watchability lift comes from a high-Cubs/low-Angels tNERD split. Taillon‚Äôs recent return delivered six efficient innings with his usual strike-throwing tempo, which plays well behind Chicago‚Äôs top-tier fielding and active baserunning. Cubs bats just torched the Angels ‚Äî Kyle Tucker went double-dinger and Reese McGuire grand-slammed ‚Äî a reminder that Chicago‚Äôs barrel rate travels.

Storyline bonus points: Hendricks faces the franchise he fronted for a decade, now tasked with navigating Tucker, Seiya Suzuki and friends while leaning on soft stuff and command. The Angels can still punish mistakes (hello, Jo Adell), but a leaky pen and a rough recent run of homers allowed make late innings feel longer than they should. Mike Trout is back in the mix, though his 22-game on-base streak was snapped last night, a tidy summary of LAA‚Äôs volatility.

The counterweight is Arizona‚Äôs bullpen, which has been one of MLB‚Äôs shakiest this year, a recipe for volatility if this stays close late. Confirmed probables: Singer vs. Gallen.

Washington Nationals @ Philadelphia Phillies, 10:35a

Summary

Ranger Su√°rez‚Äôs contact-killing efficiency against a low-miss Jake Irvin makes this more matchup watch than duel. With Zack Wheeler shelved for the season, every Su√°rez turn doubles as a stress test for Philly‚Äôs October plans.

The gNERD sits at 8.13‚Äîbelow today‚Äôs average‚Äîbut it‚Äôs buoyed by a beefy Phillies tNERD (8.52) and a pNERD edge for Su√°rez (5.27 vs. 1.64). Under the hood, Su√°rez‚Äôs profile plays: roughly a 3.0 FIP and 3.5 xFIP with a healthy K-BB rate, while Irvin arrives with road marks around 5.5 FIP/4.6 xFIP and limited whiffs‚Äîexactly the sort of contact this lineup punishes. Philadelphia‚Äôs baserunning chops (and general on-base churn) add entertainment value if they start stringing balls into the gaps, and the ninth now comes pre-shortened thanks to deadline import Jhoan Duran. For Washington, the hook is the kids: CJ Abrams, James Wood, Brady House, and Dylan Crews are here, bringing swing speed and curiosity even if the team-level tNERD (0.83) and defense won‚Äôt help Irvin much. They were all on the card in this series. Overall: not a top-tier watch, but a tidy check-in on a contender adjusting on the fly behind a clear favorite on the mound.

Houston Astros @ Baltimore Orioles, 10:35a

Summary

Trevor Rogers is the draw; Houston‚Äôs bats are the wildcard. This is a below-the-marquee watch driven by a crisp lefty versus a lineup that just spent a series turning mistakes into souvenirs.

At a gNERD of 7.88 (below today‚Äôs average), the tilt leans on Rogers‚Äô strong pNERD (7.92) and skills profile‚Äîan xFIP- of 83 with above-average strike rate and brisk pace‚Äîagainst an Astros offense that‚Äôs been punishing anything elevated. Baltimore‚Äôs lefty comes in after an early-year knee scare but recent form and an 8-K outing on Aug. 1 suggest he‚Äôs very much intact. Houston, meanwhile, has thumped its way through the series‚Äîthree first-inning homers and a late Walker dagger were the latest exhibits‚Äîso contact quality will decide how long Rogers‚Äô efficiency holds. On the other side, Spencer Arrighetti‚Äôs pNERD (0.14) and rough xFIP- (134) hint at traffic; if he‚Äôs forced out early, Houston‚Äôs better bullpen (positive tNERD component) becomes the feature while Baltimore‚Äôs weaker pen and defense dim the undercard. A preview note that Rogers has logged one-run starts deep into games lately only sharpens the contrast. Verdict: not premium, but compelling for Rogers vs. a loud lineup with seventh-inning plot-twist potential.

Minnesota Twins @ Chicago White Sox, 11:10a

Summary

This is today‚Äôs gNERD floor special, but curiosity has a pulse: Taj Bradley‚Äôs Twins debut after the deadline swap for Griffin Jax meets Yoendrys G√≥mez‚Äôs ‚Äúcan he stick as a starter?‚Äù audition. If pitching-development experiments are your thing, keep a window open; otherwise, you won‚Äôt miss art. Bradley-vs.-G√≥mez is a lopsided pNERD (5.26 vs. -1.25) inside a low-average tNERD matchup, which is why this game‚Äôs 5.50 gNERD sits at the bottom of today‚Äôs slate. Bradley brings mid‚Äë90s juice and age-based upside, with underlying results that are fine-but-not-elite (xFIP living in the low‚Äë4s and notably better vs. righties), and the fresh‚Äëuniform novelty helps. G√≥mez has a thin track record but was stretched out and popped in his first start (5 IP, 7 K vs. DET) and later beat ATL, so there‚Äôs at least variance-based intrigue. The Twins‚Äô biggest entertainment feature is actually the bullpen (a strength by our inputs), while Chicago‚Äôs offense/defense lag. The series has already produced a Royce Lewis grand slam and Colson Montgomery‚Äôs first career grand slam, so a bat‚Äëgets‚Äëhot subplot is alive even if the overall watchability is not.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on August 23, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Boston Red Sox @ New York Yankees, 10:05a

Summary

If you‚Äôre picking one game, pick this one: today‚Äôs highest gNERD (17.03) meets Yankees‚ÄìRed Sox stakes and contrast‚Äîan ace lefty who misses bats versus a lineup built to dent scoreboards. It‚Äôs also a rubberneck special: Boston has seven straight over New York, owns the tiebreak, and just won 1-0 behind more crisp run prevention than pathos.

Boston‚Äôs top-10 tNERD rides barrels, gloves, and a plus bullpen, and the headliner is Garrett Crochet (pNERD 11.82), whose 96 mph heat and a 64 xFIP- say ‚Äúgood luck‚Äù to a power-first opponent; he held the Yankees to one run over 8.1 IP in June and has allowed two earned or fewer in 10 of his past 13 starts. New York‚Äôs watchability comes from thunder‚Äîthis group just became the first team ever to hit nine homers in a game twice in one season‚Äîyet that same power has masked sloppier edges Boston‚Äôs defense and ‚Äòpen can exploit. Will Warren (pNERD 5.24) is the wild card: his cartoonish sweeper now leads MLB in horizontal break and has recently steadied him (two ER or fewer in seven of eight), a pitch-design subplot worthy of your remote. Net it out: top-of-day gNERD, elite K stuff versus record-setting pop, and real playoff leverage‚Äîwell above the 95th percentile of historic gNERDs‚Äîmake this appointment viewing.

Cleveland Guardians @ Texas Rangers, 4:05p

Summary

Prospect sizzle vs. contact craft: Jack Leiter‚Äôs 97 and new sinker/change meet Logan Allen‚Äôs brisk, pitch-to-contact lefty pace ‚Äî a style clash that could move quickly. With Texas down Evan Carter and Marcus Semien‚Äôs foot still a question, runs won‚Äôt come easy, which is part of the appeal. gNERD sits at 8.56 ‚Äî below today‚Äôs average ‚Äî because the pNERDs are light; neither starter screams dominance. Leiter‚Äôs stuff is loud, but the indicators are middling (roughly 4.40 FIP/4.62 xFIP), and his last turn was a short, three-runs-in-3.2-innings stumble; the intrigue is whether the revamped arsenal holds up against a contact-leaning lineup. Allen counters with more modest bat-missing but comparable estimators (about 4.34 FIP/4.41 xFIP) and a snappy tempo that keeps the ball in play and the game watchable. The team-side pull comes from Cleveland‚Äôs defense/baserunning and a bullpen that‚Äôs been top-tier by FIP, versus a Rangers offense that‚Äôs been below average lately ‚Äî meaning late leverage could tilt toward the visitors. Also, yes, Leiter vs. Jos√© Ram√≠rez and Corey Seager vs. Allen are worthwhile individual chess matches even if the overall watchability is mid-tier.

Cristian Javier‚Äôs post‚ÄìTommy John reboot meets Dean Kremer, who just spun seven scoreless with seven strikeouts against this very lineup; intrigue beats pure stuff here. Baltimore is doing this without Adley Rutschman, now back on the IL, so rookie Samuel Basallo and a wobbly bullpen become the swing factors rather than star power.

By the numbers, this sits below today‚Äôs average gNERD, and the modest pitcher/two middling team NERDs say ‚Äúbackground TV‚Äù‚Äîunless you‚Äôre curious about Javier 2.0. He‚Äôs altered the mix (new sinker, less four-seam) and, in a tiny sample, is more control-first than bat-missing; the FIP/xFIP trail his headline line, and his last outing ended early with an illness and a small velo dip. Our model likes Houston‚Äôs bullpen relative to Baltimore‚Äôs, and the series opener reinforced why: the Orioles‚Äô relief leaked runs while Houston held on. Summary

Prospect intrigue meets patience test: a middling gNERD gets a lift if, as multiple outlets indicate, Mick Abel takes the ball for Minnesota opposite a resurgent Davis Martin. The White Sox‚Äôs offense drags the watchability, but a likely rookie cameo and some recent fireworks nudge this above ‚Äúskip.‚Äù

Chicago rolls with Martin, who just logged six scoreless with eight groundouts in Kansas City, the latest hint that his current form outpaces league-average peripherals flagged by pNERD. If he keeps living in the zone with the cutter/change, this could be tidy rather than noisy. Minnesota‚Äôs starter is the swing factor: signs point to Abel, newly acquired in the Jhoan Duran deal and fresh off strong Triple-A work after debuting earlier this year, which adds novelty even if pNERD can‚Äôt price him yet. The Twins‚Äô bullpen has been the comparatively entertaining part of their roster and just slammed the door with Justin Topa getting the final five outs last game, a nice fit with the positive tNERD bullpen component.

As for the bats, Minnesota has been uneven but Royce Lewis‚Äôs grand slam reminded us there‚Äôs thump; the Sox remain a low-wRC+ bunch despite cameos from Colson Montgomery and Kyle Teel, which explains the subpar tNERD. Expect competence more than chaos‚Äîunless the kid makes it weird.

Philadelphia‚Äôs lineup-and-legs machine versus a contact-prone Mitchell Parker screams ‚Äúruns,‚Äù while Aaron Nola‚Äôs second start back from a long IL stint determines whether this is watchable pitching or pure offense. Add the subplot of Zack Wheeler‚Äôs blood-clot absence, and Nola‚Äôs outing suddenly feels weight-bearing for an NL East leader.

With a gNERD of 7.61 (below today‚Äôs average), the watchability lift comes from the Phillies‚Äô strong 8.43 tNERD‚Äîplus top-tier baserunning‚Äîagainst a Nationals club whose tNERD is 0.83 and whose fielding and bullpen grade poorly. On the mound, Nola‚Äôs pNERD (4.80) and xFIP- of 89 suggest he‚Äôs better than last week‚Äôs ragged return, when Washington reached him for six in 2.1 innings after his ankle/rib layoff; Saturday offers a clean read on whether his command normalizes. Opposite him, Parker‚Äôs 1.16 pNERD and 126 xFIP- fit the scouting-by-math: few whiffs and a slower pace that can snowball against an aggressive order. Their rematch comes days after both were chased early in the same game. Washington just nicked the opener 5-4 thanks to Dylan Crews and Daylen Lile heroics, so the kids have fresh credibility if this turns late and close.

Summary

Today‚Äôs gNERD floor comes with one hook: Mike Burrows‚Äô rookie upside paired with the Pirates‚Äô run‚Äëprevention chops. Tune for his mid‚Äë90s fastball and brisk pace against a Rockies lineup that grades poorly by batting runs, and to see whether Kyle Freeland‚Äôs FIP‚Äëover‚ÄëERA gap finally closes. Burrows (pNERD 6.7) has ridden the usual rookie turbulence, but he‚Äôs rebounded well and Pittsburgh is managing his workload after Tommy John. The Pirates just blanked Colorado 9‚Äë0, with fellow kids Braxton Ashcraft and Bubba Chandler starring‚ÄîChandler even logged a scoreless four‚Äëinning save in his debut‚Äîuseful context for a staff that our inputs already like. With Oneil Cruz on the concussion IL, the Pirates‚Äô offense is thinner, which keeps the ceiling modest. Freeland (pNERD 3.8) works quickly and fills the zone; his 2025 FIP has lived in the mid‚Äë4s while the ERA sits north of five, hinting at better skill than results. Net: gNERD 6.57 says ‚Äúbackground game,‚Äù but a live rookie arm and competent run prevention give it a mild upgrade.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on August 22, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

8.7 4:35p St. Louis Cardinals 5.7 Tampa Bay Rays 5.9 Miles Mikolas 1.9 Adrian Houser 3.9

6.7 4:05p Houston Astros 4.7 Baltimore Orioles 3.0 Lance McCullers Jr. 0.0 Cade Povich 5.7
5.6 3:40p Colorado Rockies -0.4 Pittsburgh Pirates 3.2 Antonio Senzatela 0.4 Braxton Ashcraft 8.0

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Boston Red Sox @ New York Yankees, 4:05p

Summary

Top of today‚Äôs watchability board: Red Sox‚ÄìYankees gets the gNERD crown, and the stakes match the noise. Max Fried tries to steady a recent skid while Brayan Bello reprises the June duel he won.

Even with only average pNERDs, the teams do the heavy lifting: New York‚Äôs thunder (best-in-class barrel rate and run creation in our inputs) meets Boston‚Äôs tNERD cocktail of elite defense, smart baserunning, and a deep bullpen‚Äîan entertaining contrast that should keep traffic on the bases and leverage high late. Bello‚Äôs profile‚Äî95 mph with grounders‚Äîplays in any park, but the FIP/whiff mix leaves little cushion in the short porch, particularly versus lefties; note he spun seven scoreless against the Yankees in June, even if his indicators sit nearer league-average.

Fried still kills lift with a heavy ground-ball game and generally strong peripherals, yet a July blister and a run of bumpy outings have made him more storyline than sure thing of late.

Layer in a tight wild-card race and a rivalry the city would love to feel again, and this grades as the day‚Äôs best bet for drama, with bats and bullpens likely deciding it more than the marquee arms.

Toronto Blue Jays @ Miami Marlins, 4:10p

Summary

If you‚Äôre tuning in for one thing, make it Shane Bieber‚Äôs return to a big‚Äëleague mound in a new shade of blue. Toronto‚Äôs deadline swing for the 2020 Cy Young turns into a debut, and his rehab line ‚Äî 37 strikeouts in 29 innings ‚Äî hints there‚Äôs still whiff in the weaponry.

This gNERD sits near the top of today‚Äôs slate, and the model agrees with your eyes: Toronto‚Äôs high tNERD is powered by real strengths ‚Äî plus batting runs, elite defense, and a top‚Äëtier on‚Äëbase and slug profile ‚Äî which raises the ceiling even if Bieber‚Äôs workload is capped. The Jays‚Äô lineup ranks near the top in AVG/OBP/SLG, so there‚Äôs support if Bieber needs a soft landing. Miami, meanwhile, hasn‚Äôt confirmed a starter after rotation churn; Cal Quantrill had been listed, but reports indicate he was just claimed by Atlanta, so this could tilt bullpen‚Äëheavy. Injuries haven‚Äôt helped the Marlins ‚Äî Max Meyer and Ryan Weathers are shelved, and Kyle Stowers is out ‚Äî lowering their tNERD and thinning run‚Äëprevention options. As a bonus subplot, former Toronto signee Otto Lopez lines up against his old organization.

Net: a watchable test of a marquee comeback backed by a strong supporting cast against a short‚Äëstaffed opponent, with gNERD saying you could do much worse today.

Cleveland Guardians @ Texas Rangers, 5:05p

Summary

Nathan Eovaldi is the draw here: a top-tier pNERD (7.92) backed by a month-long tear and an eight-inning, one-hit blanking of the Yankees on August 5 that showcased why he was Pitcher of the Month in July. Cleveland‚Äôs counter, Slade Cecconi, brings strike-throwing and a tweaked sinker/cutter mix‚Äîbut also volatility, as Atlanta just tagged him for eight runs on August 17.

With a gNERD of 11.69, this sits near the top of today‚Äôs slate and comfortably above the historical median‚Äîmostly on Eovaldi‚Äôs side of the ledger and Cleveland‚Äôs sturdy run-prevention profile. Eovaldi‚Äôs recent line points to true skill (xFIP- 72 in the model; plus whiffs and strikes), and Texas‚Äô elite run prevention keeps games taut even while their bats sag. Cleveland‚Äôs offense is punchless but their defense and bullpen are watchable strengths, though they‚Äôre navigating life without Emmanuel Clase through August 31. The gNERD sits at 8.31‚Äîbelow today‚Äôs average‚Äîbecause the pitching side is light (avg pNERD 3.82) and Washington‚Äôs tNERD is near the floor, but Philadelphia‚Äôs robust 8.21 tNERD keeps this watchable. Taijuan Walker has stabilized by leaning harder on a cutter and trimming walks, yet indicators (e.g., FIP in the ~5s) and an average-ish xFIP- suggest less bite than the ERA implies.

As for aesthetics, Philly‚Äôs bats and baserunning (see the strong tNERD components) raise the entertainment ceiling, while Washington‚Äôs leaky defense and shaky bullpen threaten late-inning entropy. If Cavalli carries over the whiffs he‚Äôs teased‚Äîand if Trea Turner‚Äôs hot month keeps humming‚Äîthe matchup plays above its gNERD; otherwise, this tilts toward a competent Phillies machine grinding through a thin opponent.

If you like ‚Äúprove-it‚Äù outings against a tweaked ballpark backdrop, this one has just enough bite to sample.

At 6.71, the gNERD sits below today‚Äôs slate average, and the reason is on the mound: Povich‚Äôs above-average pNERD (5.73) faces McCullers‚Äô near-zero, a tidy summary of ‚Äúdeveloping arm versus rust and command.‚Äù The model‚Äôs read lines up with the skills: Povich‚Äôs August shows bat-missing life (32% K, xFIP ~3.2; his season away split carries a mid‚Äë3s xFIP), which plays against an offense that‚Äôs looked oddly mortal. Meanwhile, McCullers only just returned from a 915‚Äëday layoff in May and is being asked to go again right off a blister IL stint‚Äîplenty of story but not much recent precision.

There‚Äôs also the setting: Camden‚Äôs moved-in left-field wall has nudged right-handed power back toward normal, subtly boosting watchability for Astros bats if they square one. If it tilts late, note the contrast our numbers suggest‚ÄîAstros‚Äô pen as a relative strength‚Äîwith Houston scrambling after a Hader injury and bringing in Craig Kimbrel to stabilize the endgame.

The NERD split says it all: a lopsided pNERD (Ashcraft 8.0 vs. Senzatela 0.4) propping up two low tNERDs. Ashcraft brings legit stuff‚Äîfour-seam averaging ~97 with a 91‚Äì92 slider and a usable curve‚Äîwhich fits his solid run prevention so far and the pNERD-friendly xFIP- of 90. Expect strikes and velocity rather than whiff-a-palooza. Meanwhile, Senzatela‚Äôs profile is contact-forward to a fault: minimal swing-and-miss, a 125 xFIP-, and a season full of loud contact, even if he did flash five scoreless in his IL return last week. Offenses won‚Äôt rescue the watchability‚ÄîPittsburgh ranks last in HR and slugging and remains short a top-end athlete with Oneil Cruz on the concussion IL‚Äîso the intrigue is mostly Ashcraft vs. Colorado‚Äôs bats and whether Senzatela can steal soft contact. entry.title: MLB: What to watch on August 21, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Score Time (PT) Visitors Score Home Score Starter (V) Score Starter (H) Score
15.1 11:20a Milwaukee Brewers 9.9 Chicago Cubs 9.9 Quinn Priester 6.5 Shota Imanaga 3.8
13.0 1:05p New York Mets 10.9 Washington Nationals 0.5 Sean Manaea 7.2 MacKenzie Gore 7.3
12.6 4:15p Boston Red Sox 8.8 New York Yankees 8.3 Lucas Giolito 3.1 Luis Gil No data

10.8 1:10p San Francisco Giants 3.4 San Diego Padres 7.7 Justin Verlander 2.9 Dylan Cease 7.6
9.3 10:10a Athletics 7.4 Minnesota Twins 4.2 Jack Perkins No data Jos√© Ure√±a 2.0

7.5 12:10p Los Angeles Dodgers 7.5 Colorado Rockies -0.3 Clayton Kershaw 3.5 Chase Dollander 4.2
7.4 4:15p Houston Astros 4.6 Baltimore Orioles 3.0 Jason Alexander 3.0 Brandon Young 4.2

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Milwaukee Brewers @ Chicago Cubs, 11:20a

Summary

Today‚Äôs top-rated gNERD meets near‚Äì95th-percentile historic territory, and it earns it. Two athletic clubs that run and glove well square off in a division race that actually matters, with a lively pitcher contrast to match.

Milwaukee‚Äôs and Chicago‚Äôs tNERDs are both near 10, driven by plus baserunning and defense, so expect action on balls in play rather than a walk-fest. Our model likes Quinn Priester more than you might expect (pNERD 6.5, above the historic 75th percentile), thanks to an above‚Äëaverage xFIP (xFIP‚Äë 92) and a brisk pace that keeps the game moving. Shota Imanaga‚Äôs pNERD trails, but he‚Äôs trending well: three straight quality starts, including seven innings of one‚Äërun ball his last time out, and since returning from a hamstring strain in late June he‚Äôs run a sparkling 51:5 K:BB, i.e., premium strike‚Äëthrowing without freebies.

There‚Äôs also real stakes: Chicago has won five of six to trim the gap, while Milwaukee cooled after a 14‚Äëgame heater, which only sharpens the edges here.

Net: elite team watchability plus contrasting arms‚Äîcommand artist vs. efficient, above‚Äëaverage bat-muter‚Äîmake this the game to prioritize.

New York Mets @ Washington Nationals, 1:05p

Summary

Strikeout theater vs. barrel brigade: MacKenzie Gore‚Äôs whiffs against a Mets lineup that lives on loud contact makes this 12.95 gNERD one to prioritize. If you like a little chaos, Washington‚Äôs bullpen tends to supply it, and Sean Manaea‚Äôs recent wobble adds combustible late-inning potential.

Both starters carry strong pNERDs (~7.2). Gore‚Äôs been the headliner: mid‚Äë90s heat, a nastier breaker mix, and a season built on K power after a 13‚Äëstrikeout, no‚Äëwalk Opening Day that set a Nationals record and foreshadowed elite swing‚Äëand‚Äëmiss rates. The Mets bring today‚Äôs top tNERD, driven by a team barrel rate around 10.4% (league ~8.6%), so every mistake can leave a dent. Manaea‚Äôs profile still grades fine under the hood (xFIP‚Äë 89, quick pace), but his recent August turns were short and choppy, which matters because New York‚Äôs starters haven‚Äôt been buying many innings lately. On the other side, Washington‚Äôs weakest link has been its relief corps, which owns the league‚Äôs worst ERA, so even a Gore gem can unravel once the gate opens. Net effect: high watchability via a premium K artist facing premium contact, with real chances for late swings‚Äîstatistical and literal‚Äîthanks to the contrasting tNERDs and the bullpens behind them.

Boston Red Sox @ New York Yankees, 4:15p

Summary

A rivalry game with numbers to match: a gNERD 12.56 and two top-tier tNERDs say this one‚Äôs driven by bats and bullpens more than by headline aces. It‚Äôs the Yankees‚Äô power in a short-porch park versus Lucas Giolito‚Äôs comeback, while recently returned Luis Gil tries to land strikes more often than souvenirs. The watchability case is strong: 12.56 sits above today‚Äôs slate average and around the historic 75th percentile, with both teams‚Äô tNERDs buoyed by hard contact (NYY) and Boston‚Äôs fielding/baserunning-and-deep-pen profile. New York‚Äôs run differential and Statcast quality of contact trends support the ‚Äúbring-your-bleachers‚Äù vibe, even if their bullpen wobbles, a tension that keeps late innings lively. On the mound, Giolito‚Äôs pNERD is modest, but he‚Äôs fresh off 6.1 innings of one-run ball and, post‚Äìinternal brace surgery, has looked more steady than splashy; the short porch will test any homer propensity. Gil‚Äôs pNERD is zero only because of small sample: since rejoining the rotation he‚Äôs logged 14 IP with 14 K but 8 BB‚Äîencouraging stuff, inconsistent command‚Äîplus a solid win last time out. If this tilts bullpen-heavy, Boston‚Äôs group (projected top-10) and recent roster shuffles add intrigue against a Yankees relief corps that‚Äôs been more volatile.

St. Louis Cardinals @ Tampa Bay Rays, 4:35p

Summary

Craft vs. chaos is the hook: Sonny Gray‚Äôs surgical profile meets Joe Boyle‚Äôs 100-mph volatility, with St. Louis‚Äôs gloves and Tampa Bay‚Äôs legs deciding the margins. At a gNERD of 11.46‚Äîsolidly above today‚Äôs average‚Äîthis is a worthy channel surf stop for fans of contrasts rather than slugfests.

Gray‚Äôs stronger pNERD (7.36) is driven by a sub-80 xFIP- and plus strike-throwing, so the watch here is sequencing and whiffs over radar-gun theater. Boyle brings the latter in spades but a lighter pNERD (3.85); the Rays have retooled him with a lower arm slot and a new ‚Äúsplinker,‚Äù which pairs with triple-digit heat but still flirts with walk trouble, i.e., high-variance innings. St. Louis‚Äôs team-side appeal is defense and bullpen stability (tNERD 5.74 with standout fielding), a real on-screen feature that helps keep Gray‚Äôs contact manageable. The Rays counter with motion: they‚Äôve been among MLB‚Äôs most larcenous on the bases, so every single can become television. Lineup-wise, note the Cards are thin without Nolan Arenado and Brendan Donovan, nudging this toward a run-prevention watch rather than a fireworks show. If you like precision vs. raw stuff plus baserunning chaos, this sits in the upper-middle of the day‚Äôs slate for watchability.

Verlander‚Äôs pNERD lags, but there‚Äôs intrigue: he‚Äôs still mid‚Äë90s and publicly tinkering to ‚Äúfind it,‚Äù and he‚Äôs coming off a crisp, zero‚Äërun, eight‚ÄëK turn that hints at more than the surface shows. Team-wise, San Diego‚Äôs tNERD rides a bullpen that was already a strength and then added Mason Miller at the deadline‚Äîexactly the sort of move that shortens games and spikes late‚Äëinning drama. The Giants‚Äô tNERD is pulled down by a light offense (team wRC+ 94) and shaky contact quality, a tough fit against Cease‚Äôs bat‚Äëmissing. If Jackson Merrill‚Äôs recent ankle issue keeps him out, that nicks some Padres offense, but the arms still headline.

It‚Äôs Kershaw vs. Dollander, and the gap shows in tNERD (Dodgers 7.54, Rockies -0.31). Kershaw isn‚Äôt missing many bats (5.7 K/9), but he‚Äôs on a three‚Äëstart quality streak, just held San Diego to one run over six, and already logged six one‚Äërun innings at Coors. Dollander brings 97.9 heat, but the line reads 5.53 FIP, a thin chase rate, and 15 HR in 78.1 innings‚Äîespecially vulnerable to lefties. Relative to today‚Äôs range (7.44‚Äì15.08) and historical distributions, this lands below‚Äëaverage in watchability, but curiosity points accrue: a command artist coaxing soft contact at altitude and a live arm trying to harness it before the Dodgers‚Äô deep lineup and superior pen put things out of reach.

Houston Astros @ Baltimore Orioles, 4:15p

Summary

Brandon Young just flirted with Orioles history against these Astros; now he gets them again, making this rematch more interesting than its modest gNERD suggests. On the other side, quick-working Jason Alexander has quietly stacked two crisp, scoreless six-inning starts, which pairs nicely with Houston‚Äôs sturdy bullpen.

At 7.44, today‚Äôs gNERD sits at the floor of the slate, and the components explain why: average-ish pNERDs (3.60) and middling team bats, with Baltimore‚Äôs tNERD dragged by shaky defense/bullpen while Houston‚Äôs is propped up by a strong ‚Äòpen and a big positive Luck signal hinting at regression to better results. The hook, though, is real: six days ago Young carried a perfect game into the eighth vs. Houston before an infield single ended it, his first MLB win, and he‚Äôll try to back it up at Camden Yards.

Alexander counters with a sinker/changeup profile, works fast (17.1s), and just blanked Miami then held the Yankees to one hit; if he keeps it on the ground, this could move briskly and hinge late‚Äîwhere F√©lix Bautista‚Äôs season-ending shoulder surgery and Josh Hader‚Äôs IL stint tilt the relief edge toward Houston‚Äôs depth. Wild card: Yordan √Ålvarez started a rehab assignment this week and could reappear in Baltimore, a watchability boost if activated.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on August 20, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Milwaukee Brewers @ Chicago Cubs, 5:05p

Summary

Top gNERD on the board, and it earns it: a 23-year-old, triple-digit rookie comet meets a contact-minded veteran in a rivalry with real standings bite. If you like contrast‚Äîpower vs. speed, whiffs vs. barrels, youth vs. guile‚Äîthis has it.

Jacob Misiorowski brings 99‚Äì103 with a vicious breaker, fresh off a mid‚ÄëAugust return from a brief IL stint; the stuff has been loud enough to draw national ink, and the pNERD (11.35) says the bat-missing is real even if the command wanders. Colin Rea isn‚Äôt a whiff machine, but he‚Äôs tweaked his mix‚Äîmore four-seamers, a gyro slider‚Äîand leans on soft contact to get through turns; pNERD (2.54) flags the lower sizzle, but the pitch-shape makeover is legit. The Brewers‚Äô identity is speed and prevention‚Äîelite defense with a go‚Äëgo running game that set a theft record this spring‚Äîand that juice shows up in a top-shelf tNERD. The Cubs counter with barrels and thump across the order, a profile that plays if they square up the heater. Layer on divisional stakes‚Äîdivision-leading Brewers versus a Cubs club coming off a doubleheader sweep‚Äîand the watchability writes itself.

Seattle Mariners @ Philadelphia Phillies, 10:05a

Summary

Top-shelf watch: a gNERD of 13.39 puts this well above today‚Äôs average, marrying Philly‚Äôs basepath chaos with a whiff-forward lefty in Jes√∫s Luzardo against Seattle‚Äôs thunder-and-miscues profile. Luzardo‚Äôs velocity pop and tinkering (new sweeper, four-seam‚Äìheavy looks) meet Luis Castillo‚Äôs good-but-volatile baseline‚Äîprime territory for both punchouts and dents in the outfield padding.

Texas hasn‚Äôt officially named a starter; listings vary from TBA to Kumar Rocker to even Jacob deGrom, though deGrom is reportedly sidelined until at least Aug. 25, so plan for uncertainty. With Royals ‚ÄúLuck‚Äù running hot in our model and Texas bringing plus defense and baserunning, this leans toward a tidy, low-scoring watch where Cameron‚Äôs pitchability and Witt‚Äôs star power give K.C. the style points.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on August 19, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

6.3 5:40p Los Angeles Dodgers 7.5 Colorado Rockies -0.4 Emmet Sheehan 5.7 Austin Gomber -0.3

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Houston Astros @ Detroit Tigers, 3:40p

Summary

Two aces, little margin: Tarik Skubal (reigning AL Cy; ~30% K‚ÄìBB, ~2.35 xFIP) faces Michigan-born Hunter Brown (top‚Äë10 WHIP) in the day‚Äôs highest gNERD tilt.
Add Detroit‚Äôs thump and Houston‚Äôs Hader‚Äëless bullpen, and any crack after the starters becomes theater.

Skubal‚Äôs pNERD 13.80 matches the eye test: elite strikeout and walk rates with sub‚Äë0.90 WHIP and best‚Äëin‚Äëclass run prevention by fielding‚Äëindependent metrics. Brown‚Äôs pNERD 8.33 is no slouch either, pairing ~2.9‚Äì3.1 xFIP with a ~22% K‚ÄëBB%, and he‚Äôs on a mini‚Äëheater (four runs in his last 19 innings) while returning to his home state. The gNERD 17.60 sits atop today‚Äôs slate and above the 95th percentile historically, thanks to two premium pNERDs plus a style contrast: Detroit‚Äôs higher‚Äëoctane tNERD (8.16) is buoyed by power‚Äëbarrel bats and competent defense, while Houston‚Äôs tNERD (4.89) leans more on a sturdy bullpen. Recent context nudges the intrigue‚ÄîTigers just administered a 10‚Äì0 drubbing as Houston‚Äôs offense hit a skid (three shutouts in four), and Yordan √Ålvarez is only just starting a rehab assignment. Meanwhile, the Astros‚Äô late‚Äëinning plan is thinner with Josh Hader on the IL. None of that guarantees outcomes, but it sharpens the edges of an already must‚Äëwatch matchup.

Milwaukee Brewers @ Chicago Cubs, 5:05p

Summary

Peak-woodruff versus IL-return Taillon, with two high-tNERD clubs that run, field, and generally make baseball look brisk‚Äîthis gNERD 16.25 clash sits near the top of today‚Äôs slate and above the 95th percentile historically. If you can spare one game for stakes and style, this is it.

Milwaukee‚Äôs watchability comes from speed and leather (elite baserunning and plus fielding in tNERD), backed by a steadier bullpen than Chicago‚Äôs, while the Cubs counter with barrels and defense of their own; that symmetry raises the floor on long, competitive at-bats. On the mound, pNERD tilts toward Brandon Woodruff (8.31), whose xFIP- is an excellent 74 and whose club has won all seven of his starts since returning, a tidy summary of miss rates and weak contact rather than empty ERA sheen. Jameson Taillon (4.44) returns from a calf strain for his first big-league start since late June; he looked sharp in rehab (5.1 scoreless at Triple-A) and works quickly, but his xFIP- (105) and contact profile are the risk against Milwaukee‚Äôs on-base-and-go approach. With the Brewers up big in the Central and the doubleheader reshuffle confirming Woodruff‚ÄìTaillon in this pairing, the narrative juice matches the numbers.

Milwaukee Brewers @ Chicago Cubs, 11:20a

Summary

Chaos vs. clockwork: Milwaukee‚Äôs pressure-cooker baserunning and defense crash into Matthew Boyd‚Äôs All-Star metronome. At a gNERD 14.89, this sits near the top of today‚Äôs slate and above the 95th percentile historically, and it comes freshly remixed by a rain-created doubleheader reshuffle.

Milwaukee‚Äôs high tNERD is earned the old-fashioned way: they run, catch, and squeeze extra value from the margins, a formula that‚Äôs powered a league-leading record and a midseason tear built on elite defense and aggressiveness. Mets-heavy watch: a top-barrel offense meets one of MLB‚Äôs leakiest defenses, with David Peterson capable of keeping the throttle steady. This isn‚Äôt an ace duel so much as ‚Äúcan Washington catch it while Jake Irvin finds fixes?‚Äù

The gNERD (9.26) sits a bit below today‚Äôs average, but the split explains the draw: Mets tNERD is near the top of today‚Äôs board while the Nats‚Äô is near the bottom, so entertainment tilts toward New York‚Äôs bats and chaos on Washington‚Äôs side of the ledger. Peterson‚Äôs pNERD is modestly above average and the underlying says competent (xFIP- ~90), plus he already authored his first career complete-game shutout against these Nationals in June, a useful reminder of the matchup fit. Irvin‚Äôs pNERD is low and his recent run has been rough (winless this month with a 9.45 ERA over his last three), which pairs poorly with the Nats‚Äô error-prone infield. If Francisco √Ålvarez sits after a thumb scare (MRI pending), that dings some Mets oomph, but Francisco Lindor‚Äôs fresh NL Player of the Week nod keeps the lineup‚Äôs watchability high. In short: not a pitchers‚Äô clinic, but plenty of hard contact, baserunners, and a fair chance the gloves become part of the story.

Cincinnati Reds @ Los Angeles Angels, 6:38p

Hunter Greene‚Äôs 100 mph-and-splitter reboot is the draw; the Angels‚Äô bottom-tier glove work and wobbly run prevention mean you‚Äôre likely to see both whiffs and fireworks. Kyle Hendricks counters with precision, but his contact profile at home‚Äîespecially vs. righties‚Äîhands Cincinnati‚Äôs right-handed bats a real window.

This sits a tick below today‚Äôs average gNERD, but it leans watchable because the pNERD split is lopsided: Greene (11.93) over Hendricks (1.99). Greene‚Äôs stuff/command jump is real‚Äîroughly 11.0 K/9 against just 2.1 BB/9 with a ~3.4 FIP‚Äîand he returned throwing 11 pitches at 100+ while mixing a splitter that keeps lefties honest. Hendricks brings guile, yet his run estimators are closer to average (4.8 FIP overall) and at Angel Stadium he‚Äôs been vulnerable to righties (home vs RHB: .362 AVG, 5.95 FIP, 4.46 xFIP). The Angels do offer watchable thump‚ÄîTaylor Ward pacing them in homers‚Äîplus Mike Trout is back as a DH, even if still managing a knee, but Los Angeles‚Äô defense/bullpen have trended toward ‚Äúadventure,‚Äù and they‚Äôve allowed 18 homers over their last 10 games. Add Cincinnati‚Äôs plus baserunning and you get a clean narrative: Greene‚Äôs strikeouts and Reds pressure versus Angels contact and loud mistakes.

At a gNERD of 8.89, it‚Äôs a mid-table watch by today‚Äôs standards (10.93 average), but the stakes and styles nudge it up. Texas gets the slight pNERD edge because Kelly‚Äôs underlying run prevention (xFIP- 91) outpaces Lugo‚Äôs (106), and the Rangers just traded for him precisely for outings like this. The entertainment here is less about thunder and more about texture: Lugo works quickly and leans on contact management, while both clubs suppress runs as well as almost anyone (team ERAs: TEX 3.44, KC 3.60). Offensively, the inputs say ‚Äúmodest‚Äù‚Äîboth teams grade negatively in batting runs and barrels‚Äîso defense and bullpen leverage should carry the drama; note Kansas City‚Äôs sturdy relief group and a whiff of positive ‚Äúluck,‚Äù which could wobble in tight spots. Texas is shorthanded with Adolis Garc√≠a on the IL, further tilting the game toward gloves and gap-to-gap singles, while the Royals‚Äô rotation has been held together by Lugo amid injuries elsewhere.

Come for Boston‚Äôs team-speed-and-glove show, stay to see whether two name-brand starters with modest pNERDs can thread enough strikes to let the game breathe. This rates below today‚Äôs slate by gNERD, but the Red Sox‚Äôs high-tNERD ingredients make it more watchable than the headline pitching would suggest.

With a 7.25 gNERD (well under today‚Äôs average), the matchup leans on Boston‚Äôs strengths: plus defense and lively baserunning that tends to manufacture action; they‚Äôve been among the better fielding groups by midseason defensive composites, and they run often (108 SB on the team page), both reliable watchability additives. Tomoyuki Sugano vs. Walker Buehler is confirmed, but the pNERD pair (1.24 vs. 1.37) and xFIP- marks (113, 118) suggest contact over whiffs. Sugano‚Äôs storyline helps: he just logged his 10th MLB win and has stabilized after a bumpy midyear stretch. Buehler, on a one-year prove-it in Boston, has flashed better pace but was touched for four in six his last time out. Baltimore‚Äôs rebuild subplot adds novelty, too, with 21-year-old Samuel Basallo newly promoted and getting real run. If you want crisp team baseball more than ace-vs-ace theatrics, this fits the bill.

Los Angeles Dodgers @ Colorado Rockies, 5:40p

Summary

Power-vs.-pitch-to-contact at altitude alert: the gNERD sits at the bottom of today‚Äôs slate because one side (Gomber/Rockies) suppresses watchability, but the Dodgers‚Äô bats and bullpen keep this from a hard pass. There‚Äôs also a curiosity factor: Emmet Sheehan‚Äôs rehab-year return gives you a mid‚Äë90s look with real bat-missing potential and just enough volatility to keep the remote nearby.

Sheehan is back in the rotation post‚ÄìUCL surgery (activated June 18) and, while his last turn yielded five runs to the Angels, his underlying indicators are playable: season xFIP lives in the low-4s and improves with the bases empty (xFIP ~3.2), hinting that sequencing more than stuff has hurt him so far. The lineup behind him has clicked for 15 homers in the last 10 games, and the bullpen grades top‚Äëfive by FanGraphs‚Äô preseason model, both watchability pluses. On the other side, Austin Gomber‚Äôs profile is the drag: soft whiffs and a .312 opponent average this year, the textbook ‚Äúcontact in play‚Äù starter, now facing Ohtani/Betts et al. Combine that with Colorado‚Äôs bottom-tier offense and beleaguered pen and you get our low gNERD: run-scoring interest, limited two-way quality.

entry.title: MLB: What to watch on August 18, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Milwaukee Brewers @ Chicago Cubs, 11:20a

Summary

Top of the slate alert: this gNERD 14.55 rivalry tilt is driven by two high-tNERD clubs that catch it, run it, and should keep the ball in play just enough to stay tense throughout. Add a lively rookie (Cade Horton) versus a bat-missing metronome (Freddy Peralta), and you‚Äôve got appointment TV, not background noise.

Peralta‚Äôs watchability comes from skills, not smoke: he‚Äôs running a 25.5% K rate with a 3.66 FIP and tidy 1.08 WHIP profile, and the four-seamer/secondary tweaks undergirding that (flatter approach angle, firmer velo around 95 mph with xERA near the mid‚Äë3s) remain very real. Horton‚Äôs pNERD edge (6.51) reflects the novelty: mid‚Äë90s heat, a slider scouts loved, and he‚Äôs arriving off a career‚Äëbest 8‚ÄëK start; as a 2025 call‚Äëup, there‚Äôs discovery value every inning.

The tNERD heft is the sell: both defenses grade among the league‚Äôs best, and Chicago in particular has been hyper‚Äëefficient on the bases, a trait Milwaukee also leverages. That dovetails with Peralta‚Äôs bat-missing profile and Horton‚Äôs quick tempo to keep pace crisp. Context helps: Milwaukee rolls in with a top record and a sizable division cushion, while the Cubs‚Äô lineup has enough thump to test mistakes.

Milwaukee Brewers @ Chicago Cubs, 5:05p

Summary

Two top-10 tNERD clubs with very different thrills‚ÄîMilwaukee‚Äôs speed/defense vs. Chicago‚Äôs barrels‚Äîmake this one of the slate‚Äôs best watches. And if the probables hold (Freddy Peralta vs. Cade Horton), it‚Äôs NL wins leader vs. a rookie on a post-break heater, which is exactly the kind of contrast NERD was built to find.

Texas Rangers @ Kansas City Royals, 4:40p

Summary

A watchability snack, not a feast: gNERD 8.0 puts this below today‚Äôs average, but Wacha‚Äôs contact craft vs. Leiter‚Äôs premium velocity has just enough sizzle to keep you around for seconds. With Adolis Garc√≠a on the IL and two low-octane offenses, expect every run to be wrung out of the margins.

The profiles are tidy: Michael Wacha‚Äôs run prevention has portable backbone (3.74 FIP, low walks), and Kauffman‚Äôs big gaps fit his contact-management approach like a bespoke suit. Jack Leiter brings 97‚Äì98 and a revamped two-seamer/change, but his 4.40 FIP says the command-and-contact game is still a work in progress.

This tilts ‚Äúpitching watch‚Äù because both lineups have been more beige than bold: Texas is hitting .232 and leans on run prevention; Kansas City‚Äôs staff is excellent while the bats lag (26th in OPS, power light). That dynamic, plus a solid Royals pen and a park that suppresses big flies, nudges entertainment toward tense, ball-in-play innings rather than fireworks.

NERD-wise, the modest pNERDs (Leiter 2.75, Wacha 3.69) match the eye test: one veteran winning with execution, one live arm still finding the edges. If you like sequencing, changeups and outfield routes, this lands in the ‚Äúworthy background game‚Äù tier‚Äîwith a small side of KC ‚Äúluck‚Äù to monitor.

Cincinnati Reds @ Los Angeles Angels, 6:38p

Summary

Brady Singer is the adult supervision here; the rest is watchable chaos. The Angels whiff a ton, field poorly and might run a bullpen day behind spot‚Äëstarter Victor Mederos, which is how a modest gNERD can still produce entertainment.

At 6.51, this sits near the lower end of today‚Äôs slate, dragged down by weak team components: the Angels‚Äô defense grades near the bottom by multiple systems and their bullpen has bled runs, while the Reds‚Äô bats have slumped since the deadline despite solid baserunning. Singer‚Äôs pNERD is middling, but he‚Äôs fresh off six scoreless with five Ks, and his quick pace helps the TV product. Opposite him, Mederos brings a thin big‚Äëleague track record and uncertain length, a recipe for traffic. The Angels counter with power and strikeouts‚Äîfun when contact is made, volatile when it isn‚Äôt‚Äîand Mike Trout has recently rejoined the lineup as a DH, adding name‚Äëbrand swing decisions if not guaranteed thump. If you‚Äôre tuning in, it‚Äôs for Singer‚Äôs efficiency, Elly and friends testing the run game, and the late‚Äëinning potential for Angel chaos.

Otherwise, this sits at the bottom of today‚Äôs gNERD range because Chicago brings a light bat and a volatile spot-starter profile.

The 6.08 gNERD reflects modest tNERDs (ATL 4.63, CHW 2.86) and a lopsided pNERD split: Strider‚Äôs 6.82 keeps this watchable, powered by a still‚Äëgood xFIP‚Äë (93) and velocity, even if his last outing went sideways; he also notched his 500th K earlier this year in his return. entry.title: MLB: What to watch on August 17, 2025
entry.content:
Here are today's MLB games, ordered by watchability, based on how interesting the teams and starting pitchers look. Higher is better. For more information, read this post.

Notes:

  • Pitcher 'no data': Pitchers only have a pNERD score once they've started at least one game and have at least 20 innings pitched. I also show 'no data' when I can't correctly link a starting pitcher with their stats.
  • Generated by the mlb-watchability project on GitHub.

Detail

Miami Marlins @ Boston Red Sox, 10:35a

Summary

This is mostly worth watching because Garrett Crochet is the kind of pitcher who makes every inning feel consequential; Miami‚Äôs Janson Junk provides enough unpredictability that the game rarely feels dull. The very high gNERD (15.69) comes almost entirely from Crochet‚Äôs pNERD (11.88) and Boston‚Äôs stronger team profile, so expect a pitcher-driven game that tilts toward strikeout-heavy swings and defensive plays.

Crochet pairs top-end velocity and swing-and-miss stuff with an outstanding underlying profile (elite xFIP and a season full of strikeouts), which explains why he‚Äôs the main attraction and why his starts tend to be watchable. Junk‚Äôs profile is the opposite: a journeyman lefty recently worked into Miami‚Äôs rotation after a minor-league deal and call-up, offering decent control but far less swing-and-miss upside, so his starts invite either length or a quick bullpen parade. Boston‚Äôs team metrics (better barreling, fielding and bullpen components) amplify the mismatch and the chances this turns into a one-sided outing ‚Äî or, if Junk tangles a few hitters early, a tense bullpen chess match. Overall: prioritize this for Crochet‚Äôs strikeout theater and the tactical late-innings possibilities; don‚Äôt expect a high-offense slugfest.

Seattle Mariners @ New York Mets, 4:10p

Summary

Quality matchup on paper: George Kirby‚Äôs high-end stuff (pNERD 8.68) vs. a Mets lineup and roster that scream watchability (tNERD 8.98), which pushes this game into the upper tail of interest (gNERD 13.01). The headline is simple ‚Äî Kirby is the reason to tune in: his underlying profile (excellent xFIP-, elite command history and mid-90s velo) is what drives that pNERD and makes every inning matter.

Clay Holmes is a less compelling counter: a converted reliever with an average xFIP- and a low SwStr/zone footprint in this matchup (pNERD 3.03), and recent starts have shown both workload questions and some command wobble as he settles into a starter‚Äôs role.

Beyond the arms, the Mets supply big offensive perks ‚Äî above-average barrel rate, baserunning, and a bullpen that boosts their team NERD ‚Äî while Seattle‚Äôs offense has pop but shakier defense, which sets up a decent clash of tidy starting pitching against an eventful lineup.

If you prize pitcher-driven chess and a chance to see an elite young arm test a hitter-friendly club, this one‚Äôs worth prioritizing; if you want raw back-and-forth offense regardless of pitching, lower your expectations.

Tampa Bay Rays @ San Francisco Giants, 1:05p

Summary

If you like watching an ace try to shut everything down, this one‚Äôs worth a seat: Logan Webb‚Äôs profile makes the game a pitching event, and the numbers say he‚Äôs the reason to tune in. Webb‚Äôs pNERD (9.39) is the standout here ‚Äî his scant xFIP- and leap in strikeouts make him both high-floor and high-drama on the mound, and he‚Äôs been the Giants‚Äô clear staff ace this season. Ryan Pepiot (pNERD 5.85) is no slouch: above-average velocity and a decent K profile mean he can keep this competitive, but he‚Äôs a notch below Webb‚Äôs dominance. Team-wise, the Rays (tNERD 6.39) bring youthful athleticism and excellent baserunning that can manufacture action despite mediocre power and shaky defense, while the Giants‚Äô weak offense and recent home struggles ‚Äî compounded by Matt Chapman landing on the IL ‚Äî mute spectacle at the plate. The gNERD (11.80) sits above today‚Äôs average, so expect a mostly cerebral, pitcher-driven contest: pick it if you prefer quality starts and strategic at-bats, skip it if you need fireworks.

This one‚Äôs worth tuning into because you‚Äôve got a genuine top-end arm against a quietly menacing lineup‚ÄîEovaldi‚Äôs the story, Berr√≠os the counter‚Äîand the Jays‚Äô offense just showed it can blow a game open. Nathan Eovaldi‚Äôs high pNERD (7.88) reflects an excellent xFIP- (72) and strong strike/whiff profile, so when he‚Äôs on he forces contact into low-value places and piles up Ks; that makes every early-inning at-bat feel consequential. Jos√© Berr√≠os (pNERD 2.30) grades much lower: his xFIP- sits above average (106) and his swing‚Äëand‚Äëmiss/strike rates are underwhelming, so this has the shape of a pitcher‚Äôs duel tilted toward Texas rather than a bullpen arms race. Toronto‚Äôs tNERD (6.81) is buoyed by huge batting runs and good defense, and they just thumped Texas 14‚Äì2 yesterday ‚Äî George Springer was activated and bolsters that offense ‚Äî so expect a lineup that can punish any mistake. The Rangers‚Äô tNERD (5.77) leans on baserunning and fielding despite a thin bat. Overall gNERD 11.38 is a hair above today‚Äôs mean, signaling an above-average watchability mostly because of Eovaldi vs. a hot, deep Blue Jays offense.
